verses.verse: ((1 Eliphaz reprehendeth Job, because he ascribeth wisdom and pureness to himself.16 He describeth the curse that falleth on the wicked, reckoning Job to be one of the number.) ) Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said,

Shall a wise man speak words of the (That is, vain words, and without consolation?) wind? and fill his belly (Meaning, with matters that are of none importance, which are forgotten as soon as they are uttered, as the East wind drieth up the moisture as soon as it falleth.) with the East wind?
Shall he dispute with words not comely? or with talk that is not profitable?
Surely thou hast cast off (He chargeth Job as though his talk caused men to cast off the fear of God, and prayer.) fear, and restrainest prayer before God:
For thy mouth declareth thine iniquity, seeing thou hast chosen the (Thou speakest as do the mockers and contemners of God.) tongue of the crafty.
Thine own mouth condemneth thee, and not I, and thy lips testify against thee.
Art thou the (That is, the most ancient, and so by reason the most wise?) first man that was born? and wast thou made before the hills?
Hast thou heard the secret counsel of God, and dost thou restrain wisdom (Art thou only wise?) to thee?
What knowest thou that we know not? and understandest that is not in us?
With us are both ancient and very aged men, far older than thy father.
Seem the consolations of God (He accuseth Jobâ€™s pride and ingratitude, that will not be comforted by God, nor by their counsel.) small unto thee? is this thing strange unto thee?
Why doth thine heart (Why dost thou stand in thine own conceit?) take thee away, and what do thine eyes mean,
That thou answerest to God (Hebrew, in thy spirit.) at thy pleasure, and bringest such words out of thy mouth?

What is man, that he should be clean? and he that is born of woman, that he should (His purpose is to prove that Job as an unjust man, and an hypocrite is punished for his sins, like as he did before, Job 4:8.) be just?
Behold, he found no steadfastness in his Saints: yea, the heavens are not clean in his sight.
How much more is man abominable, and filthy, which (Which hath a desire to sin, as he that is thirsty to drink.) drinketh iniquity like water?
I will tell thee: hear me, and I will declare that which I have seen:
Which wise men have told, as they have heard of their fathers, and have not kept it secret:
To whom alone the land was (Who by their wisdom so governed, that no stranger invaded them, and so the land seemed to be given to them alone.) given, and no stranger passed through them.
The wicked man is continually as one that travaileth of child, and the number (The cruel man is ever in danger of death, and is never quiet in conscience.) of years is hid from the tyrant.
A sound of fear is in his ears, and in his prosperity the destroyer shall come upon him.
He believeth not to return out of (Out of that misery whereunto he once falleth.) darkness: for he seeth the sword before him.

He wandereth (God doth not only impoverish the wicked oft times, but even in their prosperity he punisheth them with a greediness evermore to gather: which is as a beggary.) to and fro for bread where he may: he knoweth that the day of darkness is prepared at hand.

Affliction and (He showeth what weapons God useth against the wicked, which lift up themselves against him, to wit, terror of conscience, and outward afflictions.) anguish shall make him afraid: they shall prevail against him as a king ready to the battle.
For he hath stretched out his hand against God, and made himself strong against the Almighty.
Therefore God shall run upon him, even upon his neck, and against the most thick part of his shield.

Because he hath covered his face with (That is, he was so puffed up with great prosperity and abundance of all things, that he forgat God: noting, that Job in his felicity had not the true fear of God.) his fatness, and hath collops in his flank.

Though he dwell (Though he build and repair ruinous places to get him fame, yet God shall bring all to naught, and turn his great prosperity into extreme misery.) in desolate cities, and in houses which no man inhabiteth, but are become heaps,
He shall not be rich, neither shall his substance continue, neither shall he prolong the (Meaning, that his sumptuous buildings should never come to perfection.) perfection thereof in the earth.
He shall never depart out of darkness: the flame shall dry up his branches, and he shall go away with the breath of his mouth.

He (He standeth so in his own conceit, that he will give no place to good counsel, therefore his own pride shall bring him to destruction.) believeth not that he erreth in vanity: therefore vanity shall be his change.
His branch shall not be green, but shall be cut off before his day.
God shall destroy him as the vine her sour (As one that gathereth grapes before they be ripe.) grape, and shall cast him off, as the olive doth her flower.
For the congregation of the hypocrite shall be desolate, and fire shall devour the houses of (Which were built or maintained by powling and bribery.) bribes.
For they (And therefore all their vain devises shall turn to their own destruction.) conceive mischief and bring forth vanity, and their belly hath prepared deceit.
